clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of Carotid Peak Systolic Velocity Variation With Aortic Peak Systolic Velocity Variation in Pediatric Non-Cardiac Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of Carotid Peak Systolic Velocity Variation With Aortic Peak Systolic Velocity Variation in Pediatric Non-Cardiac Surgery

lead_sponsor.agency: Postgraduate Institute of Medical Education and Research

clinical_study.source: Postgraduate Institute of Medical Education and Research

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to evaluate whether carotid Doppler peak systolic velocity can be an easy to measure possible surrogate for echocardiographic measurement of aortic peak systolic velocity variation which is an index of fluid responsiveness in mechanically ventilated children intra-operatively.

primary_outcome.measure: Comparison of carotid peak systolic velocity variation with aortic peak systolic velocity variation
primary_outcome.description: Comparison of carotid peak systolic velocity variation with aortic peak systolic velocity variation by Bland-Altman analysis

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation between aortic peak systolic velocity variation measured from apical and suprasternal windows
secondary_outcome.description: Correlation between aortic peak systolic velocity variation measured from apical and suprasternal windows by Bland-Altman analysis

arm_group.description: Children aged 1-12 years undergoing major surgeries under general endotracheal anaesthesia with mechanical ventilation under neuromuscular blockade

intervention.intervention_name: Measurement of aortic and carotid Doppler peak systolic velocity variation
intervention.description: Aortic peak systolic velocity variation to be measured by echocardiography from apical five chamber and suprasternal windows alongwith carotid peak systolic velocity variation by Doppler ultrasound simultaneously at intermittent time points intermittently.

Exclusion Criteria:
- Known congenital heart disease
- Any non-sinus rhythm, arrhythmias
- Patients on vasoactive medications
- Chest wall deformities, situs non solitus (eg. dextrocardia)
- Patients scheduled for open chest surgeries
- History of neck surgery/ carotid interventions
